Literature Review: The concept of partial identification has emerged as a pivotal framework in econometrics and statistics, addressing the limitations of traditional identification strategies in uncovering the exact values of parameters of interest. This literature review delves into the recent developments in partial identification, focusing on the methodologies for characterizing identified sets and their applications in various empirical contexts. The foundational premise of partial identification is that, in many empirically relevant scenarios, it is not feasible to pinpoint the exact value of a parameter due to inherent uncertainties or model limitations. Instead, researchers can delineate a set of values within which the parameter must lie, given the data and model assumptions. This approach has been particularly useful in the analysis of treatment effects, where the exact impact of an intervention may be obscured by unobserved heterogeneity or selection bias. Recent advancements in the field have introduced sophisticated frameworks for conducting partial identification analysis. These include the use of shape restrictions and optimizing behavior to tighten the bounds on the identified set, thereby enhancing the precision of the inferences drawn. Shape restrictions, for instance, leverage prior knowledge about the functional form of the relationship between variables to impose constraints on the possible values of the parameter. Optimizing behavior, on the other hand, incorporates assumptions about the decision-making processes of agents to further refine the identified set. The literature has also seen a surge in the application of partial identification techniques to a wide array of empirical questions, ranging from the evaluation of policy interventions to the estimation of demand elasticities. These applications underscore the versatility and robustness of partial identification as a tool for empirical research. Moreover, the development of computational algorithms and software packages has facilitated the implementation of partial identification methods, making them more accessible to researchers. In conclusion, the field of partial identification continues to evolve, offering powerful tools for addressing the challenges of empirical research in the presence of uncertainty and model limitations. The recent developments surveyed in this review highlight the ongoing efforts to refine the methodologies for characterizing identified sets and to expand the scope of their applications. As the literature progresses, it is anticipated that partial identification will play an increasingly central role in the empirical sciences, providing a rigorous foundation for inference in complex and uncertain environments.
